Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2012 12:27PM AlwaysHope wrote: Being young is certainly unusual but its not a death sentence.  I was in the chatroom 9 years ago when a young lady came in who was diagnosed at 26 years old.  She is doing amazing things with her life now and is doing very well.  You really need to wait for the biopsy results and try to stay away from statistics.  You are not a statistic. Stats are usually based on women diagnosed 10, 15 or even 20 years ago Treatment has come a LONG way and most are surviving BC. Bottom line:  don't cash in the 401K yet.  You're probably going to need it when you retire at 65.

Posts.Title: Angry!!!! Insurance Issues Analemma Analemma

Posts.Content: Feb 4, 2009 11:39AM AlwaysHope wrote: Yup, sounds about right.  Last year (2007) they tried to deny paying my scans saying that we didn't get 'pre approval'.  It took a year fighting with them to get the scans paid.  This year(2008) I constantly reminded everyone along the line to get the scans pre-approved so when the person  in my onc's office who handles this calls, Anthem says 'Oh, we don't require those to be pre-approved anymore' so no approval number was given.  Sure enough my onc submitted the claim on my scans that were done well before Thanksgiving and the story is 'you didn't get these pre-approved so we will need a copy of the medical records to determine if these were medically necessary.'  Its frustrating beyond belief.  Then, since Anthem is in another state, the instructions are that the claims and paperwork are submitted through the 'local' branch of BCBS.  So, the requested data was sent the early part of December to the 'local' BCBS and for some unknown reason, Anthem hasn't 'received' the requested information.

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2014 05:52AM AlwaysHope wrote: Hi Lin123, welcome to the stage 3 forum.  It is very hard after treatment is over.  One day you are busy with doc apts and a care team, the next you are all done and on your own.  It can be disconcerting on what to do with all your free time and worry about recurrence.  I was a triple negative so that meant no tamox or arimidex.  It is just watch and wait.  Recurrence is always a possibility.  It's hard not to worry about it.  It may seem impossible but the worry will gradually decrease with time.

Posts.Content: Apr 14, 2009 07:21PM AlwaysHope wrote: Would a triple negative breast cancer be dependent on estrogen production?  I'm a triple neg and my bc was not related to estrogen as far as I know.  I take no post treatment drugs like Tamoxifen or any of the AI's.  So, it could be possible for a young girl who has not started her mensas to develop breast cancer.  As long as there is breast tissue, you can develop it.  Even in males, since we have seen an increase in male breast cancers as well.  Please feel free to correct me if this is not right.  I'm not 100% sure.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 12:58PM AlwaysHope wrote: Skin/nipple sparing was not an option for me because I have Inflammatory bc which is in the skin of the breast. But if I had another kind I would certainly have gone that route. And if my first doctor wouldn't do it I would have no problem going to another doctor for a second opinion. The most important thing in this journey is having a doctor you can TRUST and who LISTENS to YOU. If that is not the case, run to another doctor! If this is a general surgeon see if you can find one who specializes in breast/oncology cases. Mine is a Breast Specialist (its on his office business cards) and all he does is breast cases. Nothing else. I love him! (in a purely platonic way :) )
Posts.Title: Stage and grade of cancer determined AFTER surgery. What!?! InTheWind InTheWind
Tube Tops Verses Sports Bras SheriVery Roberta77

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 12:42PM AlwaysHope wrote: One thing that has bothered me to no end is a nurse giving these opinions. I have every respect for nurses but they are not physicians. Only a physician should be telling you that skin sparing or nipple sparing is not an option. And if this physician won't even consider it then why not get a second opinion. You need to decide this before surgery because after it will be to late. It may be that they get in and find that is really isn't possible but you need a physician who will try to consider your opinions and decisions. If it is possible then they should do everything they can to consider your wishes. Its YOUR body.
Posts.Title: Stage and grade of cancer determined AFTER surgery. What!?! InTheWind InTheWind

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 01:07PM AlwaysHope wrote: Even if skin/nipple sparing is truly not an option, the Diep reconstruction seems to be very successful with those who went that route. Those on the board who had it done have been very pleased. There are several threads regarding their Diep journey and results. It is not vain or shallow to want to preserve your breast as much as possible. I would not let anyone even try to go down that road. Just tell them to STFU already. And I never curse but stuff like this just makes me angry. It is a form of bullying someone who is very vulnerable. I think you have time to arrange a second opinion. I really encourage you to do so.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 08:19AM AlwaysHope wrote: Hi I was diagnosed with Inflammatory bc, triple negative, 9 years ago. I did 5 rounds of neoadjuvant chemo which was FAC (5-Flouraouracil, Adriamycin (Epirubicin's sister) and Cytoxan (Cyclophosphamide). This chemo combo kicked my fanny but it also knocked my 14 x 10 cm 'tumor' down to less than 1 cm by the time I had mastectomy.
Posts.Title: Neoadjuvant chemo FEC100 protocol MYL MYL

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2009 08:53AM - edited Apr 10, 2009 08:54AM by AlwaysHope My steri-strips were still on when I did my first chemo.  I was kind of fast tracked to get started on chemo.  It really worked out okay.  I was a little worried as well but it hurt a little but I hate needle sticks and still preferred a little soreness over getting stuck over and over in my arm. I left the steri-strips on for about a week and my surgeon removed them on my follow up visit with him a week out of surgery.

Posts.Content: Dec 21, 2010 07:27AM AlwaysHope wrote: Bluesky Clinical depression, like post partem depression, is a biological illness.  Even the most positive people can be thrown for a loop when a major life event happens, Christian and non-Christian.  I would like to second Pure's suggestion about finding a good psychologist who can counsel you and also prescribe some medical help, if needed. Maybe it will help you to know that you are not alone.  Most of the women I know who have gone through chemo/post treatment drugs are thrown into premature menopause, which I believe is responsible for the weight gain.  I was a size 6 before diagnosis but now waddle along at a size 12.  A size 12! ...yes for my short frame and the fact that most of the weight gain is in my stomach makes me look like the prototype for the 'weebles wobble but they don't fall down' toy. Its an insult upon injury that not only do we lose our breasts but our remaining body image is dealt a severe blow.  It is what it is and learning to accept what can't be changed is a hard step to take. Go for that job interview with your best smile and the best outfit and do your best.  If they don't hire you then maybe that wasn't the job for you. Maybe its time to find a new career direction.  Is there something else you always wanted to do?

Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2012 11:25AM AlwaysHope wrote: That just sucks! Thank goodness the HealthCare reform is on track.  No more discrimination for pre-existing.  On the other hand, even with insurance, I usually had to jump through hoops and fight to have chest ct's covered and I never have had an MRI or PET because my insurance would not pre-approve.  I don't have a solution for you.  Maybe talk to the doc and see if a chest ct will do instead and then check with your local health department to see if you can get into the state/federal  breast health plan.  There are no income limitations for this program.
